quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we get super deep into the emerging role of product ops.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Frames product ops as an emerging discipline worth understanding deeply as it becomes more common in scaling organizations.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: As you'll hear in our conversation, over the past few years, this role has gone from almost non-existent to something like half of scaling tech companies with at least one product ops person.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a concrete adoption data point that signals product ops is rapidly becoming a standard function in scaling tech companies.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: This new role is probably the thing that's most changing in the role of product management.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a counterintuitive shift: the biggest change to product management may be an adjacent function rather than PM practices themselves.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We chat about what the role concretely is, how it differs from product management and project management, what to look for in your first product ops hire, how to roll out a product ops function, why product managers shouldn't be afraid of this role and how your life gets significantly better, plus, a case study on how they rolled out product ops function at a large company, and so much more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Lists practical, actionable areas (first hire, rollout, differentiation from adjacent roles) and promises a real-world case study practitioners can learn from.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Jira Product Discovery
quotes.text: Instead of dreaming up big ideas, talking to customers, and crafting a strategy, you're drowning in spreadsheets and roadmap updates and you're spending your days basically putting out fires.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Ad read)
quotes.context: Captures a common product-ops failure mode—reactive work and spreadsheet churn crowding out strategy and customer learning.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Jira Product Discovery
quotes.text: With Jira Product Discovery, you can gather all your product ideas and insights in one place and prioritize confidently, finally replacing those endless spreadsheets.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Ad read)
quotes.context: Actionable operating model: centralize inputs (ideas/insights) to enable clearer prioritization and reduce spreadsheet-driven decision making.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Jira Product Discovery
quotes.text: Create and share custom product roadmaps with any stakeholder in seconds, and it's all built on Jira, where your engineering team's already working so true collaboration is finally possible.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Ad read)
quotes.context: Highlights a practical collaboration tactic—meet engineering where they already work and tailor roadmaps per stakeholder to speed alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Jira Product Discovery
quotes.text: Great products are built by great teams, not just engineers, sales, support, leadership, even Greg from finance.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Ad read)
quotes.context: Memorable reminder that product discovery and prioritization benefit from cross-functional input beyond the usual suspects.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Jira Product Discovery
quotes.text: Anyone that you want can contribute ideas, feedback, and insights in Jira Product Discovery for free, no catch, and it's only $10 a month for you.
quotes.speaker: Sponsor (Ad read)
quotes.context: Specific pricing detail plus an operational lever: broaden contribution without adding per-stakeholder cost.

quotes.topic_title: How common product ops is now
quotes.text: The head of product operations at Uber and the person who started it, Blake Samic, is a case study in our book and he also did it at Stripe and he does it at OpenAI.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: Concrete example of a key operator repeatedly standing up product ops at multiple top-tier companies, showing how the function spreads via proven leaders.

quotes.topic_title: How common product ops is now
quotes.text: We had 365 product teams. We were trying to figure out how does this all come together, and product operations for me was a key part of it.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: A vivid scale data point that frames product ops as an integration mechanism when product org complexity explodes.

quotes.topic_title: How common product ops is now
quotes.text: When I teach CPO accelerator, when I teach people in these cohorts, out of the 20, 25 people that we'll have in a cohort, I'd say at least half of them have somebody doing something product ops related.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: A practical adoption yardstick practitioners can use to benchmark whether product ops is becoming table-stakes among scaling orgs.

quotes.topic_title: How common product ops is now
quotes.text: When we started offering this class in 2020, about 60% were products curious. As time has gone on, it's really gone down and people have started to add it. They just want to understand what's the best way to optimize it.
quotes.speaker: Denise Tilles
quotes.context: Shows the shift from curiosity to implementation, implying the new practitioner question is optimization rather than whether to adopt product ops.

quotes.topic_title: How common product ops is now
quotes.text: I think around 2019 is when Pendo started talking about product operations.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: Pins an approximate inflection point for broader industry awareness, useful for understanding how recently the function mainstreamed.

quotes.topic_title: Why product ops exists and when you need it
quotes.text: It's really about helping the product managers focus on what they were actually hired for, the strategic work.
quotes.speaker: Denise Tilles
quotes.context: Defines the core purpose of product ops as protecting PM time for strategic, outcome-driven work.

quotes.topic_title: Why product ops exists and when you need it
quotes.text: more and more product managers are taking on the data, harvesting the data, implementation and just to get data to work with, they're spending 20%, 30% of their time.
quotes.speaker: Denise Tilles
quotes.context: Gives a concrete signal and benchmark for when operational burden is materially crowding out PM effectiveness.

quotes.topic_title: Why product ops exists and when you need it
quotes.text: Product operations does not take away decision making rights from the product manager. It's there to inform them.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: Reframes product ops as decision support rather than a threat to PM ownership or autonomy.

quotes.topic_title: Why product ops exists and when you need it
quotes.text: I had to go learn MongoDB so I would stop bothering the engineers to be able to actually just measure if my products and my features were doing anything correct.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: A vivid example of PMs doing costly, non-repeatable operational work just to access basic measurement.

quotes.topic_title: Why product ops exists and when you need it
quotes.text: It's not supposed to be something that's providing more overhead. It's supposed to be something that's a little more liberating and helps free you up from all the busy work.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for how to position product ops: reduce friction and busywork rather than add process.

quotes.topic_title: Defining product ops: the three pillars
quotes.text: The way we think about it is structured around the three pillars that we talk about in the book, so business and data insights, more of the quantitative side, making sure that the product manager has all of these engagement and revenue inputs to make smart decisions, the customer market insights, so the qualitative. We talked about this a little bit earlier in terms of finding folks to speak to, making sure you're speaking to more than one just customer. Finally, the third pillar is process and practices.
quotes.speaker: Denise Tilles
quotes.context: Defines a practical three-pillar framework for product ops and clarifies what each pillar covers (quant, qual, and operating practices).

quotes.topic_title: Defining product ops: the three pillars
quotes.text: So we usually see that high growth companies start with business data and insights and make sure that they can actually monitor what they're doing and get the strategic inputs.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: Gives stage-based guidance on where product ops delivers the most leverage first in high-growth environments.

quotes.topic_title: Defining product ops: the three pillars
quotes.text: We see larger companies and enterprises go more towards the process and governance, especially if they're in, let's say, a transformation because they don't have the infrastructure to run good product.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: Highlights that in enterprise transformations, product ops impact often comes from building governance and infrastructure rather than just insights.

quotes.topic_title: Defining product ops: the three pillars
quotes.text: In that case, they're looking at even just, "How do we do roadmaps across the organization so that I as a chief product officer or VP of product can actually just have transparency into what my teams are doing?" Jira does not work for that. You need a portfolio tool to be able to roll that up into something that makes sense.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: Provides a concrete example of an ops gap (portfolio visibility) and a specific tool-level implication (Jira vs. portfolio tooling).

quotes.topic_title: Defining product ops: the three pillars
quotes.text: That's the squishy middle. When I do teach this class, I ask people what their perception is of product ops and people never think that. So that's an area definitely for growth I think at a lot of companies.
quotes.speaker: Denise Tilles
quotes.context: Calls out a commonly overlooked product ops pillar—customer/market insights—as an underdeveloped opportunity area.

quotes.topic_title: Customer and market insights vs user research
quotes.text: it's about aggregating all the interviews or customer research that's been done so people can query it and start to see what do we already know so we're not going out there and duplicating a bunch of research.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: A concrete methodology for reducing duplicated research by centralizing qualitative insights into a searchable repository.

quotes.topic_title: Customer and market insights vs user research
quotes.text: If we can build a database of people and customers that we have who opt into those types of things, it makes it easier for product managers to go out and contact them and say, "Hey, by the way, we got a beta. Do you want to do it?"
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: Actionable advice to create an opt-in participant panel that speeds up recruiting for interviews, alphas, and betas.

quotes.topic_title: Customer and market insights vs user research
quotes.text: So this is not about taking user research away from product managers or from user researchers, it's about enabling them to do it more effectively, enabling the insights to be put out across the company more effectively, and also helping them get in touch with users and get that feedback.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: Clarifies the operating model: product ops builds systems and distribution for insights rather than replacing discovery work.

quotes.topic_title: Customer and market insights vs user research
quotes.text: but usually, there's a wealth of qualitative information stuck somewhere in our organization systems, whether it's in Salesforce, whether it's in support tickets, in somebody's Google doc of their customer interviews that they've been doing, and what we're trying to do is get that out of these individual systems and into somewhere where a lot of people can take those qualitative insights and start to learn from them.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: A practical diagnosis and remedy: extract scattered qualitative signals from siloed tools into a shared learning system.

quotes.topic_title: Customer and market insights vs user research
quotes.text: Today, half of companies essentially have a product ops role and I'm guessing in another few years it'll be much higher.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A specific adoption data point that signals product ops is becoming a mainstream capability.

quotes.topic_title: How product ops changes the PM role
quotes.text: So it's either, for companies, do you want to hire 10,000 product managers and let them all do these things off the side of their desk and then concentrate on strategic work 30% of the time or do you want them concentrating on strategic work majority of the time and then help build a product operations team around them that can create these shared systems and this infrastructure to allow them to work better?
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: A clear build-vs-buy tradeoff framing for scaling product work: invest in shared ops infrastructure to increase strategic focus.

quotes.topic_title: How product ops changes the PM role
quotes.text: That's your full-time job and your OKRs and your goals are really around the outcomes for the company, you're like, "But I wrote 20 scripts this year." So we need to help them focus on the things that they're being expected to deliver in terms of value.
quotes.speaker: Denise Tilles
quotes.context: A memorable reminder to align PM effort with outcome-based expectations rather than operational output.

quotes.topic_title: How product ops changes the PM role
quotes.text: I think a lot of what gets them as well is the type of context switching that's required as a product manager.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: Highlights context switching as a core hidden cost of the PM role—one product ops can reduce by standardizing operational work.

quotes.topic_title: How product ops changes the PM role
quotes.text: Then you got to go figure out what template to put your roadmap in, which is going to be different template than the other 80 product managers on your team because somebody didn't come in and just say, "Hey, we're going to use this."
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: A concrete example of avoidable operational variance that product ops can eliminate through standardization.

quotes.topic_title: How product ops changes the PM role
quotes.text: So I work with all these CPOs, these VPs of product and they're like ... I see them just not working on strategy. I'm like, "Why are you not working on strategy?" and they're like, "I don't have time to do that. I'm in here stopping all these fires. I'm figuring out what template I should put my roadmap in."
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: Shows how operational overhead steals time from leadership strategy work—an argument for delegating ops to a dedicated function.

quotes.topic_title: What PMs should not delegate to product ops
quotes.text: You should never be outsourcing your decision making to a product ops person.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: Draws a hard boundary that PMs must retain decision rights rather than delegating product decisions to product ops.

quotes.topic_title: What PMs should not delegate to product ops
quotes.text: They're the product manager for the product managers. That's how I think about it.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: Offers a memorable mental model for product ops: optimizing the product management system, not managing the product itself.

quotes.topic_title: What PMs should not delegate to product ops
quotes.text: So their decision should be around, "How do I operationalize great product management here?" but as a product manager, you shouldn't be delegating to them to make any decisions about their product, and that's not their job.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: Clarifies the decision scope for product ops (process enablement) versus PMs (product decisions).

quotes.topic_title: What PMs should not delegate to product ops
quotes.text: No, they're not project managers, they're not the people who are going to be on top of your developers watching them build things, making sure that everything's out on time. That's not their role either.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: Prevents a common misassignment where product ops is treated as delivery/project management for engineering execution.

quotes.topic_title: What PMs should not delegate to product ops
quotes.text: They're not going to handle hard stakeholder conversations about trade-offs for you, all of those things that you are going to want to keep ownership of because at the end of the day as a product manager, your job is to produce outcomes and you do need to make sure that you're monitoring those outcomes and moving towards them.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: Reinforces PM accountability for trade-offs and outcomes, warning against offloading the hardest parts of the role.

quotes.topic_title: Go-to-market coordination and breaking silos
quotes.text: Well, there's a big piece that we're missing, go-to-market, and that's where product ops could really make a difference in terms of connecting those teams, but also being the first point of contact for sales, first point of contact for product, and enabling just some efficiencies if we want to call it process or method, but just trying to help break down the silos.
quotes.speaker: Denise Tilles
quotes.context: Defines a concrete, high-leverage role for product ops in GTM: cross-functional connective tissue and a clear interface for sales and product.

quotes.topic_title: Go-to-market coordination and breaking silos
quotes.text: So it's really talking about, "Here's how we're going to do it. Here's some simple templates we will use at training sales, training product," and then getting that into play.
quotes.speaker: Denise Tilles
quotes.context: Actionable methodology: standardize GTM execution through simple shared templates used in training across functions.

quotes.topic_title: Go-to-market coordination and breaking silos
quotes.text: So I think too what Denise was saying is product ops will take on a lot of the coordination of those types of things and making the standardized templates, but as a product manager, your role in informing what the go-to-market is doesn't change. You're still putting the inputs in there.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: Clarifies ownership boundaries: product ops coordinates and standardizes, while PMs still own the substance of GTM inputs.

quotes.topic_title: Go-to-market coordination and breaking silos
quotes.text: You still have to go talk to the salespeople. You still have to work with the marketing people to make sure it's positioned correctly, but the product ops person can help with the program management around it of getting those people together, having consistent templates, creating the cadence for when you review those things, making sure that they all align and they're all in one place so you're not going to find them everywhere, and then making sure that go-to-market process is consistent across the organization so that it's not like, as Denise said, it's not like everybody's reinventing the wheel and somebody on a go-to-market team has to figure out how to go-to-market differently with a different product team.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: Provides an operational playbook for GTM: cadence + centralized artifacts + alignment checks + consistency to prevent wheel-reinvention across teams.

quotes.topic_title: Product ops vs project and program management
quotes.text: The way I like to think about it is, however, whatever they're doing in terms of the three pillars of product ops is really thinking about, as I mentioned earlier, increasing the speed and quality of decision making and all of the pillars of play into that.
quotes.speaker: Denise Tilles
quotes.context: Defines product ops with a clear outcome-based lens—improving decision speed and quality via the three pillars.

quotes.topic_title: Product ops vs project and program management
quotes.text: Program manager, I think, is really thinking about larger company initiatives and the duration of their work is ongoing versus a project manager, they're responsible for certain project that's at a time box and an end date, but it does get a little wiffy, for sure.
quotes.speaker: Denise Tilles
quotes.context: Offers a practical distinction between program and project management by scope and time horizon, while acknowledging real-world role blur.

quotes.topic_title: Business and data insights: what product ops does
quotes.text: A lot of times, and I sit through board meetings where we talk about ARR, we talk about retention, we talk about net retention, and we talk about all of these business metrics, and they're great for monitoring the health of our business, but where product ops comes into play in business data and insights is how do we monitor the health of our product.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: Reframes product ops from reporting business KPIs to building a system for measuring product health specifically.

quotes.topic_title: Business and data insights: what product ops does
quotes.text: So as a chief product officer, ARR is interesting to me, but it's not as interesting to me as ARR by customer segment. It's not as interesting as ARR by product line. It's not as interesting if I take that and then look at it by retention or adoption by product or feature set or adoption by customer segment by product. When we start to put those lenses on it, they now become a really powerful strategy insight.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: Gives a concrete methodology: segment and slice core metrics (ARR/retention/adoption) to turn dashboards into strategy inputs.

quotes.topic_title: Business and data insights: what product ops does
quotes.text: These people make those dashboards, make those repeatable insights for you. Then ideally, they know the data so well and they know your business so well that they can surface up other opportunities for you as well to look at data that you didn't know was there or can find these interesting trends.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: Highlights the operational value of product ops: repeatable, decision-ready insights plus proactive opportunity discovery.

quotes.topic_title: Business and data insights: what product ops does
quotes.text: So product ops can help streamline things that we know we're going to look at repeatedly. There's a bunch of stuff that we know we should look at. So put them in a dashboard like, "Why should I have to go pull that report ad hoc every single time?" Put them in a dashboard, put them in a report.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to reduce repeated analytics toil by standardizing recurring metrics into dashboards/reports.

quotes.topic_title: Business and data insights: what product ops does
quotes.text: I love product ops because when we prepare for board meetings, I know there's a certain set of information that I'm going to have to put together for this board meeting, and then when we go do it manually, it becomes obsolete by the time the board meeting's over and then I got to start again and prepare for the next three months and do the board meeting again.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: A specific example showing why repeatable reporting systems matter: manual board prep becomes stale immediately and creates recurring rework.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Jira Product Discovery
quotes.text: Instead of dreaming up big ideas, talking to customers, and crafting a strategy, you're drowning in spreadsheets and roadmap updates and you're spending your days basically putting out fires.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Captures a common failure mode in product work—getting trapped in operational busywork instead of strategy and customer learning.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Jira Product Discovery
quotes.text: With Jira Product Discovery, you can gather all your product ideas and insights in one place and prioritize confidently, finally replacing those endless spreadsheets.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to centralize inputs and make prioritization a first-class workflow rather than a spreadsheet exercise.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Jira Product Discovery
quotes.text: Great products are built by great teams, not just engineers, sales, support, leadership, even Greg from finance.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable reminder that product discovery and decision-making should be cross-functional, not siloed within product/engineering.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break: Jira Product Discovery
quotes.text: We had a guest on, Casey Winters, and he has this perspective that when you have ops, operational people, that's generally a sign that something is not efficient and it could be made more efficient with software and product.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Contrarian lens: the presence of ops can indicate a process ripe for automation or productization rather than a permanent organizational layer.

quotes.topic_title: Ops as leverage: automation, sizing, and hiring
quotes.text: I think you're doing it wrong if you're doing that right. It should be a well-run lean team who thinks about how to leverage tools for this or building your own or whatever and your products for the product team, and that's how it should be seen.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: A clear operating principle: product ops should be a leverage/automation function, not a headcount-heavy service org.

quotes.topic_title: Ops as leverage: automation, sizing, and hiring
quotes.text: I don't have a hard and fast rule on that one, but I would say if you are at a one-to-one ratio, you're doing it wrong. Absolutely.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: A blunt sizing heuristic that challenges the common instinct to staff product ops per PM.

quotes.topic_title: Ops as leverage: automation, sizing, and hiring
quotes.text: So I do think there's a balance there between how good your company is instrumented both for everything, for all three of these pieces that we're talking about relative to the size of your product ops team.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: A practical mental model: ops headcount should scale with instrumentation maturity across the ops pillars.

quotes.topic_title: Ops as leverage: automation, sizing, and hiring
quotes.text: We say too, get started with one person.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: Actionable hiring guidance: start small, prove leverage, then add only when a new hurdle appears.

quotes.topic_title: Ops as leverage: automation, sizing, and hiring
quotes.text: We do see this trend of people throwing agile coaches at this, and agile coaches who have never been a product manager before in a well-run company are going to struggle there because they're going to revert back to agile processes and optimizing for things like Scrum, but they're not going to do what that role is designed for, which is to help product management processes.
quotes.speaker: Melissa Perri
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning about mis-hiring: product ops governance needs product expertise, not generic agile process optimization.
